text:
I like the flavor of the coating!  I do have one suggestion.  I tried applying the coating the way the recipe calls for (just dip in egg then coating), and also the way I learned in culinary school (dip in flour, then egg, then coating).  The latter method was much better the chicken was crispier and much juicier.  I will probably make again - thanks!

text:
This is better than the fried chicken from this site's Hall of Fame fried chicken recipe.  The crust was thick; it stuck too the chicken and browned beautifully.  I added extra spices like recommended by other reviewers: 1T seasoned salt (probably any salted spice would work that had paprika and spices), 1T of garlic powder and several variety of crackers (I didn't have any saltines).  Taste the coating, if it is pungent then it probably won't fade.  I used 2 eggs and probably 10 skinless boneless breasts.  I pounded the breasts in a plastic ziplock bag with a little water so they cooked more quickly.  I think one of the KEYS is to keep the oil hot like the recipe states, then turn it down.  Every time I added new cold pieces of chicken I would turn the flame up to high, get the oil rolling then turn it down to 3.  Also cook the chicken to a dark brown, not light golden brown.  Fried chicken is not a quick and easy thing to do so I would recommend doubling this recipe because this chicken is great the next day cold.  I always double the size of my recipes, so if you too want some good recipes that are for a large family look to my other reviews.

text:
Yum! In case you are wondering, a regular box of saltine crackers has approximately 36 crackers in a sleeve. I put all 36 crackers from the sleeve into my food processor and ground them fine. I added this, the flakes, flour, 1 T of seasoning salt, 1 tsp of pepper, 1 tsp of parsley, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp paprika. I pounded the chicken breasts between two pieces of wax paper on my cutting board, dredged the chicken in 2 beaten eggs and then coated them with the cracker mixture. I placed them in a 13x9 glass dish and baked for 45 minutes. I then melted one stick of butter and poured over the chicken breasts and baked for an additional 5 minutes. We like our chicken extra done. This had a great taste and texture without the bad for you frying! Thank you. Note: This chicken tastes delicious leftover cold the next day!!

text:
Fabulous! I can't stand it when people complain about "lacking flavor" with recipes such as this; common sense would tell me that not everyone's idea of "flavor" is the same and if it's "lacking flavor" then do something about it... salt, pepper, hot sauce, etc. I don't think it's right to give something a low rating just because it isn't EXACTLY how one person expects it to be... sorry, I just HAD to finally say something! LOL. I used all the ingredients called for and as per one user's suggestion about NOT turning frequently, I took their advice and let the chicken cook for a full 5 or 6 minutes before turning over. I then flipped the chicken and cooked for another 5 or 6 minutes and then continued to flip the chicken over for another 3 minutes on each side. The end result was juicy and evenly coated chicken that turned out to be the best tasting chicken I've ever had. My entire family is now in love with the taste and I definitely look forward to making time and time again! Aside from the great taste, I thoroughly enjoyed the mess-free factor of using the ziploc bag to do all the coating and the crackers of course were so much easier to deal with than just a basic flour coating. I think at some point in the future I will perhaps try adding a bit of a ranch powder packet in with the rest of the coating mix. This is definitely a 5 star recipe that I highly recommend trying! **Note, I used thinly sliced chicken tender type slices**

text:
Great recipe. I like my chicken thin- so the secret of pounding the chicken breast is to take a plastic bag-(gallon sized is good )& sprinkle the inside with a little water. Then place the chicken breast inside & close the seal & then you can use a mallet to pound it down with no mess. Works like a charm!

text:
Whoa, there Nellie!  This is GREAT!!!!  Had CFC from the local Chili's and looked for a recipe on this website and honestly...it's just as good.  You do need to add a little more seasoning to the flour/crax mixture though.  I added another couple of tblspoons of potato flakes, tripled the seasoning salt, added garlic powder and a tad bit of poultry seasoning.  Have made this twice in three nights (per boyfriend's request!).  First time, really pounded down the chicken - cooked very quickly and was really good.  Didn't pound chicken quite so thin second time and it was more juicy, although definitely need to turn it over several times while cooking.  Play around with the spices....don't leave the potato flakes, crackers or flour out...it makes a very tasty, crunchy crust!  Will add to my "favorites!"

text:
I don't think this chicken could be any better. Another reviewer compared this to Chili's chicken fried chicken -- no way-- this is better! I made it for a dinner party tonight and was so proud of it. Everyone raved about the chicken, and one person left with the recipe.
I pounded the chicken thin the night before and seasoned it with seasoned salt before soaking it in buttermilk overnight (makes it really juicy).
I didn't think the breading was enough so I added another half sleeve of crackers, more potato flakes, lots more seasoned salt, garlic powder, and pepper. Good thing I did-- I had just enough.
Great served with garlic smashed potatoes and green beans.

text:
This recipe is amazing!!!  I made it last night for dinner and my husband said "ummmm----" with just about every bite.  I used cracker meal sold in the store near the shake and bake.  It is a box full of crushed crackers, so that helped me save on prep time.  I had two zip lock bags, one with flour and seasoning and one with the mixture of cracker meal, potatoe flakes and seasoning.  I just kind of eye-balled it, but I used enough flour and cracker/potatoe mixture to completely coat the chicken.  The chicken breast I used were thick, so I sliced them down the middle to butterfly them and beat them like some people recommended until they were thin.  (The only thing I could think to beat it with was the back of a cookie scooper, since I don't own a meat mallet.) I was surprised that the chicken coating stayed in tack.  The secret is the order that you use to bread the chicken as stated by a few members.  1. Cover in flour 2. Cover in egg 3. Cover in cracker meal/potatoe flakes.  It was absolutely delicious.  Thank you very much for sharing!

text:
I enjoyed this and used the other suggestions from various postings of adding seasonings (garlic powder, seasoned salt, parsley, a dash of red peppers, more ground pepper, etc.)  I thought that it was pretty easy and found that if I heated up the oil really good, first and then turned it down (as it states in the recipe) that really worked out well.  The only thing I would change in the recipe is that I think it says to "continuously turn the chicken."  I let the chicken cook/fry on one side (I was using an old skillet) for a really long time (about 20 min. on one side) which gave the breaded part time to actually fry right to the chicken and didn't fall off as easily as if I were continuously turning it.  It got VERY crispy too.

The only problem was we don't have a deep fryer but a really old medium sized skillet, so it took a really long time to finish the actual frying (probably over an hour.)  Our fault, not the recipe's.

I would definitely make this again, though.

Thanks!

text:
People, don't do skinless, boneless. That is another way to say 'tasteless and dry'. Use cut up pieces, with bone and skin. Season it lightly first with salt and pepper. Then do this: 

In bowl, put 2 cups flour and add 1tsp salt, 1tsp garlic powder, 1tsp pepper. 

In another bowl, beat 3 eggs, 1/3 cup milk and 1/3 cup water. 

In a third bowl, put 2-3 cups panko or seasoned/unseasoned bread crumbs.

In large deep skillet, heat 1 cup oil till hot. 
Dip chicken in flour, then egg, then crumbs. Let sit for 3-5 minutes.

Add to skillet - don't crowd. Careful, not too hot-keep heat medium high. Season crumb coating lightly with pepper, garlic powder and little bit of paprika. Cook 5 minutes - till golden, turn over and cook another 5 minutes. Now the trick. Remove all chicken (not fully cooked) - to cookie sheet. Put in oven set at 350. Bake for 30 minutes. Remove and let sit for few minutes. This process gives the good fried taste, but doesnt cook it too long so it doesnt burn or dry out - it stays very moist. Bon apetite!!

text:
I am not really rating the recipe, but just adding a suugestion as to pounding chicken breasts or anything else you want to pound out thinner. Save the inner liner from whatever cereal you might eat and use those to pound stuff thin in. They are much tougher than plastic wrap, waxed paper or just about anything else you might use.

text:
I added some extra seasonings, a little extra seasoning salt, garlic powder and paprika. My 8 year old who is only 50 pounds and is a REALLY small eater ate 2  whole chicken breasts and my 2 1/2 yr old ate 1 whole one. Rarely do I see them dig into dinner with such gusto. This will go in the recipe book for future generations for sure!  For all who said their meat was tough... pound your chicken breasts out first. As a general rule of thumb always expect them to be tough unless you pound them, you have to break down the membranes that make them tough. And if you batter is falling off in cooking its because you did not dredge your meat in flour before dipping in the egg. If you want any batter to stick to anything ever insert that step into every recipe you batter. If it burns, your cooking it with your oil at to high of a temp, it takes just as much practice to fry chicken as it did at 16 learning to parallel park, if its brown and still not cooked just toss it in the oven at 300-325 to finish, a low heat will keep it moist and allow it to cook through which is probably safer and easier if your using bone in anyways, I petrified of serving raw chicken so I almost always throw whatever chicken I'm making the oven at 300 for a little while and have NEVER over cooked since the heat is low.

Display Name:
Jason "the cook" Stevens

text:
Here's a hint for everyone who likes their chicken super crispy. I used 20 saltine crackers and added one cup of Panko breadcrumbs to it. I added 1 teaspoon of the following spices to the recipe: garlic powder, onion powder, paprika. I also increased the black pepper to 1 teaspoon and added 2 teaspoons of seasoning salt instead of one. I also added 3 tablespoons of potato flakes instead of 2. Added all of this to a zip lock bag. it covered about 3 pounds of chicken tenderloins which is what I used. NOW HERE'S A GREAT TIP. once I ran the chicken through the egg and added it to the breading I really pressed the  breading hard onto the chicken. When you pull the chicken out of the bag you want it coated very well. Now here's the tip. Place all of the coated chicken in the refrigerator for 3-4 hours (preferably overnight). This allows the breading to adhere to the chicken so when you cook it the breading stays on the chicken and not in the pan. When you are ready to cook take the chicken out of the fridge about 1 hour before cooking. I deep fried my tenders (oil was at 350 degrees) and they took about 6-8 minutes a batch. Don't over crowd the fryer. I put in like 6-8 pieces per batch depending on size of the loin. i cooked them to a nice deep golden brown. I cooked about 30 tenderloins and the amount of breading left in the deep fryer was less than a teaspoon. Refrigerating the chicken really made a difference. Hope this helps. Great recipe!!

Fried chicken is an artform, and I have not been blessed in this department! So I spared my family and baked this instead. I placed 2 metal cooling racks in the bottom of a shallow roasting pan so the bottoms of the chicken wouldn't get soggy. Baked at 375 for about an hour, uncovered.  Was moist and crunchy, and had lots of flavor.

text:
I made this last night for my family and we all loved it.  My son went back for seconds. I would have but was too full. I did make one small change. I only added one small step to the breading process which is to have another bowl with 1/2 c. flour seasoned with a little season salt. I dredged the chicken in the flour really well and then shook off and excess, then the egg and last the cracker crumbs. I learned from watching Food Network that the flour helps the egg  stick to the chicken which in turn helps the breading stick to the chicken. It works. I served the chicken with mashed potatoes and country cream gravy over both and green beans and biscuits. What a great country meal!!  This was soooo good and a definite keeper! Thank for the recipe!

Rating:

text:
Nice crunchy crust which I love, but it
definitely needs more spices. To make the coating stick even better, first dip breasts in flour and shake off excess.  Then dip in egg and cracker crumb mixture and press it in.  Flattening the breasts or cutting in smaller strips is a good idea and saves on frying time.

text:
First off, use 2 pounds of chicken for the same amount off coating, or halve the coating and use 1 pound chicken. I also dipped in flour, then egg, then coating. For my first batch I fileted the chicken in half, and for my second batch I kept it whole.The second batch was much better. It was more tender and crispier. For cooking I only turned once. For flavor I used roasted garlic potato flakes (plus you can use the rest as a side dish). Overall, it was very tasty.

text:
Cracker crumbs work great, and I add onion powder, paprika, & garlic powder as well.  Dipping chicken (I use thighs & breasts) in flour before egg helps keep coating on.  I use more oil (1/2 cup) so it's almost deep-fried;  once each side is somewhat browned, I turn the heat down to medium/low and add 1/2 stick butter to the oil for the last 5 min per side.  100% healthy?  heck no, but how often do you eat it?  :-)

Display Name:
Red in Keds

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/294947.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would give this 10 stars if I could!  I didn't have saltines so used 1-1/2 C bread crumbs, 3 T flour, 3 T potato flakes, 1 t salt, 1 t seasoning salt, 1/8 t garlic powder; and 3 eggs.  With a meat mallet, flattened the chicken breasts to about the same thickness and cut into strips.  Took the suggestion of another reviewer and first dipped the strips into the breading mixture, then into the eggs, then again into the breading.  I refrigerated them for a couple hours (this is what I do when I make chicken-fried steak, too) and then fried in olive oil.  By far the best chicken strips I have ever had!  Kids and hubby loved it, too!

city:

country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe my entire life. I learned it from my Mother and Grandmother. We all make it with and without the potato flakes. We also use it on pork chops, the ones that have bones come out tastingthe best but the boneless are yummy too. It's also very good with lemon or lime juice dripped on it immediately after cooking and DELICIOUS with italian dressing. 

One thing I have learned that is pertinent is that to get a good, thick breadingthat does not fall off at all, go flour, egg wash then crumbs and repeat egg and crumbs if you want, or not. The important thing is refrigerating the breaded meat for atleast a half an hour.

It's a good basic recipe but with so many reviewers having to modify the recipe and with the recipe calling for frequent turning I don't see how this recipe deserves a 4 or 5 star rating. Made this for my family and was very pleased with the results.  My daughter said its the best chicken she's ever had.  And my husband loves it too. I also marinated the chicken before I made it with some lemon, basil, salt, pepper and paprika.  I will definitely be using this recipe from now on.

text:
My husband and i forgot to even talk while eating this meal! The recipe is perfect, I used a whole sleeve of saltines and ground them up to a fine crumb, added the flour, potato flakes seasoned salt and pepper as stated. I pounded out the chicken pieces dusted them with the crumb mix, dipped them in egg and then coated them in the same crumb mix. This is the only way to get a great crispy coating that sticks! I ended up frying them on each side about 4/5 minutes, drained them on paper towels and finished the fried chicken pieces up in the oven (350 for about 20 mins). Better than the restaurants!

text:
I was afraid of the instant potatoes, as I can't stand them, but they are there just for texture.  I tweaked this recipe quite a bit, adding 1 tsp each of parsley, seasoned salt, garlic powder and about 1/2 tsp of paprika.  I dipped each piece in flour, then egg mixture, then crumb mixture.  BAKED in oven at 350 for almost an hour, turning once. It's a personal thing, I can't stand the mess of frying, and don't make enough fried foods to warrant buying a deep fryer.  Came out really tasty and moist!  Will make again, using fewer crackers.

This is a good recipe but I made a few alterations for those who are dieting. :-) I used milk instead of eggs for dipping liquid. This came out very good and much less calories and cholesterol numbers.

Really easy, quick and tasty recipe.  I had this, mashed potatoes and corn on the table in a little over an hour.  Next time, I won't cook the thinner pieces as long as they burned and dried out slightly.  My own fault.  I took others' advice and dredged in flour, then egg, then the cracker mixture, then into the hot oil.  The flavor/seasoning was great (I also added a bit of garlic salt).  Thanks!

text:
Yum!  I followed this recipe exactly, except for dipping in flour mix, egg, then flour mix again as suggested by another reviewer.  Cooked according to directions and it was crispy on the outside, juicy and tender on the inside, with great flavor.  I used a cast iron skillet and drained the grease after removing the chicken and most of the "crispies", heated skillet on high, stirred in some flour, then added milk, salt & pepper, and reduced heat to make a yummy white gravy.  I'll use this recipe again & again!

userID:
2652564
Display Name:
jessica_taylor
isPro:
False
followersCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! Earlier in the afternoon when I told my boyfriend what we were having for dinner he said that he did not want chicken for dinner. Well, needless to say that is what we had for dinner and halfway through the meal he said "I retract any statement I made earlier about not wanting chicken for dinner. I don't want this chicken to ever end." I made the recipe for only two large boneless chicken breast halves and used *15 saltine crackers *3 tsp. flour & potato flakes * 1.5 tsp. garlic powder and Lawry's seasoned salt *3/8 tsp. black pepper *one medium egg...I pounded the chicken in a ziplock freezer bag with a little water...patted it dry and dredged in flour FIRST...dipped in egg...then into the saltine mixture. I let it sit in the fridge for about 30 minutes before placing in the oil...I put the oil in the pan until it was Very hot and then removed it from the heat to cool slightly before adding the chicken...when the chicken was added I placed it back on the burner set to medium heat and browned one side for 5 minutes and flipped them over for another five minutes so both sides were very crispy...reduced the heat slightly and cooked for an additional 10 minutes turning occasionally. In total I cooked the (pounded/flattened) chicken breasts about 20 minutes and even the thickest park came out perfectly white and extra juicy. THIS RECIPE IS A DEFINITE KEEPER!

text:
Love this recipe. I didn't want to take the time smashing up the saltines & was going to use bread crumbs but, at the last minute, I gave in and glad that I did. The saltines are key to the crunchy goodness of this chicken. I marinated the chicken for a few hours in buttermilk (1 cup of milk with 1 tablespoon of lemon juice). I didn't fry  but baked at 375 for about 50 minutes. You would never be able to tell that it was baked and not fried, it was that good!!! Thank you for this recipe!

WOW...!!  A defintie "KEEPER", made it last night during a snowy night in the Northeast.  A perfect meal, french fries with brown gravy and melted Mozzarella cheese & homemade crem corn.  I doubled the coating mixture, used 3 eggs and added additonal spices, garlic powder, paprika, cayanne pepper, 1/4 cup of parmesan cheese & parsley.  Also, use 1/3 cup oil and don't continously turn, brown one side completely then turn, coating mixture stays on much better.  Using the left overs today in a salad, can't wait to make this again...!

text:
Yum!! I followed the recipe EXACTLY except I used chicken tenders. Do NOT omit the potato flakes. I added a little more than suggested and it added SO MUCH flavor!! Here is the method I used to make the recipe a little easier. I crushed the crackers in a gallon sized ziploc freezer bag with a rolling pin. I then poured the crumbs into a flat round Tupperware container, along with the rest of the dry ingredients. Closed the lid and shook it all up. Then I used the same bag to pound my chicken tenders with a meat mallet. Then it was dip, coat, fry :) This worked like a charm and there were less dishes to wash and less to clean. I fried them in canola oil. TY Cassie!!

text:
This was "almost" as good as my Grandma's fried chicken. :) I never got a chance to ask my Grandma how she seasoned her chicken so I am really glad to have found this recipe. The flavor is fantastic. I actually used skinless, boneless thighs and they were amazing. The only other change I made is that I coated the chicken the way my grandma used to--dipping it in flour first, then egg, then the coating. Coating it this way is the only way I've ever been able to keep the coating from sliding off the chicken every time I go to turn it. Then I fried it in a deep pot on medium heat (I use a pot instead of a skillet so the grease doesn't splatter on the counter). It turned out beautifully! Super golden and crispy on the outside and really juicy and tender on the inside. One other tip, once my chicken is perfectly golden brown I like to place it in a paper towel-lined colander set on top of a baking sheet (to collect drips) and keep it in a 250 degree oven while I make my gravy and finish up the rest of my side dishes. This not only keeps the chicken from getting cold but it ensures that the chicken is cooked through so I don't have to overcook it in the skillet and risk burning the skin.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-01-28T06:14:21.047
helpfulCount:
6

larryb33

text:
UPDATE 2/9/12: Tried this again. This time leaving out the potato flakes, and adding 2 T parmesan, 1 extra tsp seasoned salt, 1 tsp smoked paprika, 2 tsp garlic powder, and 1/2 tsp cayenne. Even better than the first time. (I forgot the initial flour dredge and that was a mistake. It makes a big difference with this extra crunchy coating.) 
This is very good especially with some of the excellent comments from others. The chicken breasts need to be pounded down a bit so that they cook quicker and don't burn in the hot oil. I also followed the flour->egg->cracker crumb suggestion. I added garlic powder, paprika, and dried parsley. Next time, I may substitute parmesan for the potato flakes which didn't seem to add anything, and I'll probably amp up the spices as well. Still, this is a GREAT concept that's waaay better than the traditional seasoned flour or bread crumb coating. A keeper.

We really liked this chicken.  I give it 4 stars, BF gives it 5.  I took the suggestion of others and increased the seasoned salt to 1T, but I found that in combination with the saltines, it ended up being too salty for my tastes (not reflected in my rating since it was my own alteration).  Will try 1 1/2 tsp next time.  The only addition I made was a little garlic powder and I did dredge the breasts in flour before dipping in the egg.  I always cut chicken breasts in half so prolonged cooking isn't needed, which can result in burned coating or the meat becoming too dry.  Very tasty, will definitely make again.

text:
Great recipe! I made it once following the recipe to a T, and it was a bit bland, and the crust was a little soggy, with the breasts being too dry. The second time, as others have suggested, I also added garlic powder, paprika, onion powder and cayenne pepper to the cracker crumb mixture. I also dredged the chicken in the flour, then the egg, then the cracker mixture, wrather than the way you had it posted. It layered it a little thicker that way and helped to keep it crisp. Bonless skinless chicken breast is naturally pretty dry, so this time I used regualr chicken cutlets with skin and bone, and they came out very juicy! Fabulous recipe! I will continue to play with it, but I will definitely be making it again! Thanks!

text:
I really did change this up quite a lot, but I'm sure it would've been very good as written.  I used bone-in chicken parts, made the coating with extra seasonings (garlic powder, parsley, paprika and more Lawry's), and did the 3 step technique so many other reviewers recommended (flour, egg, cracker mixture).  Then, arteries be damned, I did the rest of as a traditional fried chicken since they were bone-in pieces - about a cup of Crisco, browned it on both sides, then cooked covered for about a half hour on med-low heat.  Removed the cover and back up to higher heat to crisp up at the end.  Very good!

userID:
1724509
Display Name:
Samy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a wonderful recipe...crisp, great-textured crust!  Like other reviewers I highly recommend lightly flouring the chicken before dipping in the egg and crumb mixture.  The coating then adheres perfectly creating a crisp exterior and a juicy, greaseless interior.  I used wingettes and fried them in 375 degree oil that came halfway up the sides for 20 minutes or so turning frequently.  Make sure to season the chicken itself to your personal taste before you flour it.  Don't rely solely on seasoning the flour or the finished dish will be bland.  A nice dipping sauce is a blend of apricot preserves mixed with a teaspoon of Dijon mustard and a dash of Chinese five spice powder.  Thanks CASSJW for sharing this recipe.

text:
Very Yummy!!! I did a few things differant...first, i didn't have any potato flakes, so I just added a few more crackers. Also added some garlic salt, paprika, and parsley (a few dashes of each). I covered the ckicken in flower, then egg (needed 2 eggs), then the cracker mixture. I really didn't want the heaviness of frying in oil, so I put them in a 13x9 pan, and baked at 375 degrees for 45 minutes, then melted a stick of butter, and spooned melted butter onto each piece, then baked for an addition 5 minutes. Awesome, Hubby even called leftovers for the next day!! This is definately a keeper.

text:
This recipe is definitely a keeper. I agree with "lonnarific" that some reviewers complaints are not fair. If the recipe had been called KFC Original, I would have been dissappointed because it was too crispy and didn't have 11 herbs and spices. Prepared as directed, however, this recipe lives up to its name and, as another reviewer said, rivals restaurant style Chicken Fried Chicken. I did as others suggested (and as I'm accustomed to when breading foods) and dredged the chicken in a little seasoned flour first, then dipped it in the egg wash and then in the cracker crumb breading. I can see how the skinless, boneless chicken breasts that are called for would work best, and the thin sliced ones that I used browned nicely and were moist and tender. I also made "country gravy" and mashed potatoes since that is what I'm used to having with Chicken Fried Chicken. I will definitely be making this again!

Display Name:
nhient

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great base to go off of for a quick and easy fried chicken/baked chicken recipe. What I did was that I used sesame crackers, flour, garlic salt, garlic powder, black peppers, chili powder, paprika, and New Orleans seasoning. I mix all dry ingredients together in a bowl and set aside. In another bowl I used egg beater. In another bowl I combined flour, New Orleans seasoning, chili powder, and paprika. I used chicken thighs since I prefer dark meat. (1) dip chicken in egg, then in flour, then in egg again, then in crumbs. (2) Spray pan lined with foil (3) Place chicken on pan and spray with EVOO (4) Bake at 350 degrees for about 30-40 minutes (turn the chicken over 5-10 minutes before it is done to make both sides brown evenly). Recipe turns out really well. I used this in a chicken sandwich with a spread that I mixed together (mayo and honey). Side with a salad.

text:
My husband has been begging for some homemade fried chicken, but I've never been really good at it until now!  I flattened the chicken breasts by pounding them with a mallet inside a plastic freezer bag and turned out these huge impressive portions.  Maybe the breasts were overly large to start with, so maybe I could have used a bit more egg wash and mixture, but it still worked fine.  I also followed recommendations and added a little extra seasoning salt and some garlic powder to the crumb mixture and dredged the chicken in flour first, then egg wash, then crumb mixture.  It was all a little messy, but the results were well worth it when my husband smiled!  Thanks!!

text:
I was a little skeptical with the recipe.  I usually just use mckormick seasoning and some bread crumbs but i tried and i really liked it.  Even my 3 and 5 year old ate it and they never eat anything.  I used 12 drumbsticks instead.  Definitely will make again. Thanks for this one!

UPDATE: now when I make this I make sure to salt and pepper the chicken before putting into the egg.  Also I add several splashes of Tobasco to the egg with a splash of water.  I cook in a 9inch skillet with a large lid over it.  Still comes out the same but the taste is better.  Again, Thanks for this one!

Display Name:
Theresa Hackett

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7710779.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed it the most in my family, but a few tips to the wise:     Cook in a non-stick pan, rather than stainless steel. Stuck horribly, so that all the cracker mix fell off.     Add salt (plus a little pepper) to pre-cut chicken breasts before adding to the cracker mix, or better yet, soak in a cup of salt water solution so it gets into the inside.       Add a little Garlic Salt plus some minced dried onions. I added something called KY Kernel Mix instead of regular flour.       Recommend Following advice to bake after frying for at least 7 minutes to dry out the oil. With the leftovers it feels heavy, though you don't notice it as much after cooking it the night you do it.

Very good - made the plain old chicken breast seem really special.  I made it like everyone said with extra seasoning but I only 'fried' it for about 8 minutes, it was getting very dark so I took them out and put them on a draining rack in a large pan and put it in the oven on 320 for about 15 min. to make sure it was done  but still crispy - it was perfect.  Made mashed potatoes and gravy (that went over the breast too) and fresh green beans - super dinner - thanks for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We tried this recipe last night, but with a few minor changes. We put 1 tsp season salt, 1/2 tsp pepper, and 1/2 tsp onion salt in a shallow bowl with two Tbs flour. For crackers we used Ritz. We coated the chicken strips with the seasoned flour, dipped them in the beatten egg, then coated them with crushed cracker crumbs mixed with potato flakes. We doubled everything to coat chicken strips cut from three breasts. Strips fry faster than whole pieces, so watch them carefully. It turned out so yummy...we'll defiitely make this again!

country:
None
text:
This...is...so...good!!  I mean it's THAT good. You can use boneless chicken thighs or breast. I suggest you cut them thin to cut down on cooking time. Brown well, the crust will stick better if you make it crispy and keep the oil hot.  You can use different types of crackers, I've used townhouse, ritz and club all came out great. The only change I made was to cut out the seasoned salt (as the crackers have enough salt) and add some paprika. I have a large family so I always double the amount of breading and use 1 1/2 times the amount of chicken.

text:
Very good recipe, easy to make.  Instead of seasoned salt, I added dried basil, parmesan cheese, and some Kosher salt.  Additionally, I didn't shake the breasts in a bag, rather I pressed them onto the crumb mixture on a plate... more even coating of crumbs onto breasts.  Also, I only browned them in an oven proof non stick pan and then finished the breasts in a 350 degree oven.  The breasts won't dry out that way.  Will make this again.

text:
I made this today as part of a southern style lunch I prepared for my boyfriend on his lunch break. He raved about it all day! If you have a cast iron skillet, it is great, and to ensure better flavor and cooking, pound the chicken flat between wax paper, add garlic powder, onion powder and paprika to the seasoning.  Also, double coat the chicken and use more saltine crackers and adjust ingred. accordingly, esp. adding more pepper and seasoned salt. You will need about 3 eggs for the wash. It reheats well too! It makes a good southern meal along with coleslaw, cornbread,  fruit salad, creamed corn casserole and sweet tea.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Uh.......... THIS RECIPE IS FANTASTIC!!!!!!!!   I just used it for the first time last night.  Made two batches - one for the kids (identical to the recipe) and one for me (added a few ingredients).  

For the kids, it was PERFECT, seriously, the best fried chicken I've made in a frying pan in my kitchen to date.  They LOVED it!  

The only reason I made a batch for me is because I wanted to spice it up a little....  So I put some garlic Tabasco sauce in the egg mixture and some Cajun dry seasoning in the flour/cracker mixture, and it made for some tasty, yet spicy, fried chicken!  

Oh, I also fried up some bacon before, and used the remaining bacon grease along w/ oil to fry up the chicken.

The chicken came out golden, crispy, juicy and literally perfect.  The best thing - didn't have to use a deep fryer!  Just used a pan w/ higher sides!  Nice!

I will admit prep-time was a little longer, because of the two batches.....  but it was well worth it!

If you like restaurant style chicken fingers, then use this recipe to make your chicken, just be sure to crumble the crackers the best you can, don't short yourself on that or you will get big chunks of crackers in your breading....

GREAT recipe, can't say enough good things about it!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight. I used the exact measurements for the ingredients, however, I would use more spices next time. I used 2 medium  and 1 large sized boneless/skinless breast (pounded to 1" thick, quartered. That being said, the recipe was very, very good. My husband, who doesn't particularly care for my "normal" fried chicken, ate two pieces tonight. Both my teenage daughters LOVED it! I was excited to learn through the other reviewers to flour first, egg bath next, cracker mixture last. I also followed the advice to fry on medium heat for 4 minutes each side (only flipped once)then 20 minutes in a 350 degree oven! It was perfectly done, juicy, crispy! Very very good! I will definitely make it again. Thanks for the recipe CASSJW!

text:
the chicken was a disaster, but i'm only a beginner. first of all, you need more vegetable oil. frying chicken should not be done in a skillet but in something big, and whatever you use fill up half of it with the vegetable oil. then, heat up the oil, put it at 7, that's where it should stay too. as for the batter, my boyfriend schooled me on frying chicken, after my failed attempt he came to the rescue. he got a nice medium sized mixing bowl and whipped 2 eggs, about a cup of milk, and i wanna say 2 cups of seasoned flour (all-purpose works too). he dipped the chicken in the batter and made sure it was all battered up. then he made sure the oil was done by sprinkling the batter in the oil, unless the batter starts to fry when it hits the oil, the oil is still not hot enough. then he put in the chicken one by one, he put maybe two or three at a time, but not more than that. and key is to constantly turn the chicken. now, a little advice on making sure it's cooked all the way through, cut a long slice inside the chicken so the oil will get inside the chicken, this helps also with checking whether it still needs more cooking or whether it's done. we like our chicken to be cooked all the way through, the bone could be a little bit pink and i mean like barely even pink but that's about it. he always tells me, chicken is done if it floats to the top. we added chicken as we pulled out, and like i said, his chicken came out a beautiful dark brown color, i was so mad...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW, this recipe is AMAZING. I customised it a little based on other reviews and also what I had in my pantry. 

I didn't have potato flakes, so I did without it. 

I didn't have saltines, but I had cracked pepper flavoured water crackers, so I used those instead.

I had a whole chicken (about 3.3 pounds) that I cut up into pieces, rubbed with 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon white pepper and 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper and left to season for a few hours.

I took another reviewer's comment and breaded the chicken in this order = flour, egg, coating. Shallow fried the chicken pieces in a saucepan on 2-3 minutes each side to get a golden brown crust and then arranged them in a baking pan and left them baking in the oven at 185 degrees celsius for about 15 minutes. 

I'm not a big fan of deep frying hence I went the shallow fry + bake option. The results were AMAZING!

Tip #1 - saltines in big ziplock bag and use rolling pin to crush to very fine powder very easily.

Tip #2 - Base recipe is a little bland, but still very good. Great for cooking for people with different tastes, and individuals spice it up to personal preference.

Tip #3 - Pan frying was not very fun with my larger pieces, may have been easier, and more consistent, to deep fry this.

I wasn't blown away by this recipe but it could be because I used thighs instead of breast.  If you are also using breasts forget about the crackers because it burns before it has a chance to cook all the way through.  Just do flour salt , pepper and garlic salt in a bowl and submerge the thigh in it.  Don't even have to dip in egg first.  I gave it a four stars because I didn't follow the recipe so it may have been my fault.

text:
This was pretty good. The chicken tasted good, has a nice crispy coating, and was easy to make. I used up almost all 30 crushed crackers on 2 chix breasts though. I would suggest using more.  One concern I had with this meal was the 1/4 cup of olive oil that soaked right in to the chix breading. I had to add more as I cooked and the pan was dry when i served up these for dinner. Meaning, about 1/3 cup of olive oil for 2 chix breasts. High calorie. Otherwise, this meal tasted good.

I really liked this recipe i did change it up a bit like everyone else. I added into the crumbs some garlic, parsley and chives. text:
Wow, surprisingly good taste, texture and juicy- despite the simple ingredients.  It didn't need any gravy or dipping sauce.  I did make a few alterations though- used salt, garlic powder and chili powder in place of seasoned salt.  Made it with a whole chicken, dredged in flour first and used the method mentioned by a reviewer to bake on 350 for 45 mins and add a stick of melted butter and cook 5 more minutes.  The baking method is such a time-saver.  I can't wait to make this again!

Display Name:
T Roos

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/614621.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly except for I used club crackers instead of saltines because that's what I had and I followed another reviewer's suggestion of dredging in flour before the egg (which is way better than straight to the egg. I did one without dredging first and all the crust fell off that one right away, but not the others). I don't like when people give something a bad review if they changed the recipe, but I don't think my change really made any difference on this one. It must be just me but every time I try to cook chicken on the stove it ends up burning. I had the heat turned down to almost nothing and it still burned before it got anywhere near cooked on the inside. I ended up taking it off the stove and putting it in the oven to finish cooking because I was afraid I was going to burn my house down. I'm surprised my smoke detectors didn't go off. I'll try this again but next time I'm going to bake it instead of cooking on the stove. Also, don't use whole chicken breasts unless you pound them flat because they just end up burning before they get cooked in the middle. I'll update my review when I try it again baked in the oven. I don't think it will hold a candle to the Deviled Chicken recipe on this site though. That recipe is awesome. sorry chicken fried chicken.

text:
This is an amazing recipe! My whole family loved it and it was fairly easy to prepare. I'm 14 years old and this was my first meal i ever made for my family and no one helped me. We only had chicken thighs, so i had to alter the recipe a little bit. The thighs had to cook for 25 minutes instead of 15-20 minutes, but they were soo juicy and tender. I also used oyster crackers instead of saltines and we didnt have potatoe flakes so i left that it. I added a few more spices and it turned out great. It took me a little over an hour to cook 7 chicken thighs. It was a very rewardinr recipe and is now my special. When ever there's chicken in the house, my family wants me to make it!

Holy wow this was good! I'm a total novice when it comes to frying chicken, and it doesn't usually turn out very well. This definitely changed all that. I followed the recipe pretty much exactly, except that I forgot to add the potato flakes. This was so moist and delicious I was amazed! I want to make it again tomorrow, lol! I had absolutely no problems with the breading falling off, or it being bland, it totally wasn't. I followed the tips to not flip it constantly, I gave it a good 5 minutes on each side before flipping again, and it was perfect. I will absolutely make chicken this way again!

None
text:
Absolutely amazing! I had never made fried chicken before and was really worried about how it would turn out. My boyfriend and I agreed that it was the best fried chicken we had EVER had! I did mix in a lot of extra flour, and when cooking if a piece of batter fell off I would just put flour on top of it and it stayed on. This is the best recipe ever. I have already given it to my mom and a few friends and my boyfriend already wants me to make it again (I only made it the day before yesterday!). Oh, I also added a little garlic powder, onion flakes, paprika, ect. for extra flavor. UPDATE: I now make this recipe all the time. The key is to keep the oil really hot and only cook a few pieces at a time and the breading stays on. ENJOY!

text:
Oh my gosh, this is now my favorite fried chicken recipe!  I didn't have any potato flakes, so omitted them. Also took another reviewers advice to put more spices in.  I added 1T garlic powder, 1T seasoned salt, and 1T paprika in addition to the recommended pepper.  AWESOME!  One thing that may make it easier for others that I normally do when breading anything-I use the plastic containers (disposable but reusable too)with lids that you get at the grocery stores.  It's easier to coat anything because it's easier to get the food in and out of with less mess and you can shake off the excess as well.  This recipe is so crispy and tasty!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe.

text:
So so so good! I made this for 3 of my friends for the Pats/Cowboys game yesterday and they loved it! I was a little nervous since two of them are Southerners but they agreed it was some of the moistest and crunchiest chicken they'd ever had. I made some modifications such as adding garlic powder, onion powder, smoked paprika, cayane pepper and chili powder to the mix. I also used 2 eggs and fried the chicken in a mix of vegetable, canola and chili oil. Thanks for the recommendation to cut the breasts in half and tenderize them. This recipe yielded 6 thick strips of chicken that didn't survive through half time!  Go Pats!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
we've been looking for the 'perfect' coating for chicken and just couldn't seem to find the one. We've made this one our own and love it! We make some seasoned flour, (use plenty of black pepper and a touch of cayenne and a little garlic salt) dip the chicken in that first then in the egg and then in the cracker mixture. This way the coating stays on really well. And we like good and brown. Our favorite is skinless boneless chicken thighs. It's good the next day too if you are lucky enough to have any left over. Another tip: if you have extra cracker mixture left over you don't have to throw it away - throw it in the freezer, good in there for a coAs my son says, mom this chicken is 'da bomb'.

Outstanding! Not exactly low-calorie but worth it. I love chicken fried steak but now I love this even better. I pounded chicken breasts thin- they cook up considerably faster and look nice this way. text:
This recipe is easiest and fits best in the pan if you cut up the chicken into bites or strips, but you have to double the coating since there is more surface area on the chicken pieces.  This is the ONLY WAY I do fried chicken anymore.  The best honey mustard recipe to go with this is 1 and a half cup mayo, 1/2 cup honey, and a 1/4 cup yellow mustard blended with a mixer.  It makes a ton of honey mustard, but it stores well in the fridge for other uses.

Display Name:
Allyson Hester

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6596835.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe rocks! It's much healthier than traditional fried chicken, and it tastes just as good! I added seasoned salt, garlic powder, a little paprika, and a bit of dry onion soup to the cracker mix. I had no problems with the topping sticking to the meat.  It's good to have the chicken as dry as possible before dredging it in the egg.  Also, when you originally lay the chicken in the pan, leave it on each side for several minutes, maybe 5 or so before turning it. This helps keep the cracker mixture from slipping off the chicken.  Lastly, I beat the chicken with the bottom of a beer bottle to flatten it. Hey, whatever works!:-) But it was DELICIOUS! I'll never fry chicken any other way!

This worked out well for us.  The only thing that I did differently was to buy thin-cut chicken breasts by Foster Farms and cut each slice crosswise in 1" strips to make chicken nuggets.  It saved time for me not to pound the chicken flat (which I hate to do, so messy!) and saved cooking time as well because of the thin strips.  Thank you Cassie for a great recipe that my daughter, husband and I liked equally!

text:
I just made this for dinner tonight! This was so easy to make. The most time consuming part is slicing the onion / removing fat from the chicken. Use the best quality balsamic you can find. Next time, I'll use a better quality balsamic (the dish was a tad tangy, but I like tart, so it wasn't an issue for me), mix the balsamic, tomatoes & spices together before adding to the skillet (the spices tend to clump together otherwise) and add fresh minced garlic to the skillet as the breasts simmer. This dish goes particularly well with garlic mashed potatoes and green beans, although, I think I'll try it with seasoned rice (i.e. chicken flavor) & steamed asparagus or broccoli next time to change things up a bit.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This makes fantastic fried chicken. Everyone that has tried this chicken loves it. It can be time consuming to make, but it is so worth it. I have found that adding a bit of garlic salt instead of plain salt enhances the flavor a bit. I have also nixed the potato flakes (I find them unnecessary) I would also dip the chicken into the coating rather than putting it in a bag a shaking it, since the hardest part of getting this recipe down at first is learning to make the breading stay stuck. I have found that dipping the chicken in the flour before the egg (then the cracker crumbs and then another coat of pure flour) it really makes a difference. I do two coats of this.

country:
None
text:
This recipe was very good. It was quick to make and the chicken was so tender with a nice lite coating. So much better than the frozen chicken with the thick batter like coating from the store. I only had 3 chicken breasts and just did a half a recipe no problem. I followed the recipe exactly except only did a light sprinkle of pepper as I don't care for it. If you have large chicken breasts I suggest doing a butterfly type cut on them to thin them out some so they cook evenly and the cracker coating doesn't get burnt before the center is done. I also really liked that this was not cooked in a stick of butter like many similar recipes. I thought this tasted best just made, so I would make what will be eaten that evening. This was a tasty dinner tonight, ty.

text:
Awesome, I used 2 boneless skinless breasts into small chunks/fingers and after coating dropped in hot oil for approx 3 minutes at which time they were golden brown, I then finished them off in a 350 oven for 5 minutes and they were cooked perfectly.
I didn't have any saltine crackers so I had to substitute some crushed white cheddar crackers, because of the substitution in crackers I didn't bother with any spice and the spice level was perfect for us.
Next time I will add some buttermilk and a tsp or so of hot sauce to the egg dip for some added zip.  Thanks for posting this great recipe idea!
Forgot to mention that 2 average chicken breasts made 14 good sized chicken fingers.

country:
None
text:
Overall, this was a very simple recipe to prepare and used ingredients I always have at home, which is a definite plus!  The hubby was also very happy with this meal, which is an even bigger plus as he is pretty picky, even about fried foods.  As suggested by other reviewers, I pounded out the chicken breasts and soaked them in buttermilk for 20 minutes before breading (therefore didn't use the egg).  Also added in garlic powder to the breading.  They came out uber-tender and juicy!  However, I only used three larger chicken breasts and the amount of breading was just enough for the three - if I'd used six it would have not been near enough.  This recipe is going in the books!  Thanks!

text:
Delicious!! Everyone loved it! I did make a couple of changes though. I had the time so I marinated the chicken in buttermilk, 2 cloves of garlic and 2 bay leaves. Left them in the fridge for 24hrs. In the crumb mixture i did follow the other reviewers advice and add more salt and pepper. I also added some dried onion flakes, a pinch of cayenne papper and dried thyme. I fried the chicken in olive oil instead of vegetable since its alittle healthier. The chicken was super moist and extra crunchy! This is definetely a favorite! Will be making it often!

madeRecipesCount:
43
favoritesCount:
55
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/569876.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really great base recipe! You need to add the seasonings to your liking or it will be bland. I added onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and pepper. I have to say this does not taste like traditional chicken fried chicken, I think for that effect you pretty much have to have a batter and use a deep fryer. But we still enjoyed this very much with white country gravy on top! Delicious! Also, the coating actually stayed on the chicken very well while cooking. Make sure your oil is hot before putting the chicken in the skillet or the coating will start to get mushy and fall off. After chicken has been in the skillet on high heat for about minute or so turn the heat down. Would recommened this recipe, especially if you put the country gravy on top! We used a McCormick packet of country gravy mix. YUM!! Will make this again!

text:
delicious!   Just a few additions.  I followed some of the other suggestions from other smart cooks.  I used two beaten eggs to dip into the crumb mixture made up of:  1 sleeve of saltine crackers, 2 T flour, 2T potato flakes, 1 T black pepper, 1 T seasoned salt, 1 t parsley flakes, 1 t garlic powder, 1 t paprika and 1T cajun seasoning.  I pounded my chicken breasts only semi-thin...perfection.  My husband thought it was so delicious he ate 3 pieces, so there were no leftovers to try cold tomorrow.   Will definitely make this again.  Would like to try it with all different chicken pieces.

WOW! This was amazing. This recipe is easy and it will not disappoint you. I've been trying recipe after recipe to find a home made chicken tenders recipe that I like. I love tenders dipped in honey, but when I go out to a restaurant for them the sodium levels are so high somebody like me who is watching their sodium intake due to blood pressure runs into many problems. With this recipe I was able to control the sodium by using low sodium saltines and a sodium free seasoning mixture and still spoil myself with some outstanding tenders. I can't get over how tasty and crispy these were. I'm wondering--- can anybody tell me how long would I deep fry the pieces if I choose to make bone in fried chicken with this breading? Thank you so much CASSJW for an outstanding recipe. I will make it often.

text:
I had to pound and cut two breasts due to difference in size and thickness.  As a result I didn't need to fry a piece as long, and (naturally) needed additional coating ingredients.  Standing over a stovetop, tending to a dish, is not a fave pastime of mine(!), but when we're  in the mood for fried food---this recipe will be at top of list ;^)  The saltines add a very nice texture and I think it helped to cut the 'deep fried taste' of fried food (in general).  Dredged in flour, dipped in egg, then potato flakes.  Flopped pieces around in bag of crushed saltines, then fried.  All coating remained intact.  It's very good fried chicken!

text:
This was great!!! I made it last night and everyone loved it... I put the milk and egg together in a bowl. The I took the flour, garlic powder, pepper, salt, italian seasoning and mixed it together in a bowl. Then the crackers and potato flakes in a zip lock bag. crushed the crackers up untill really fine. Took the boneless chicken first i dipped it in the flour secondly i put it in the milk and eggs thirdly I put the chicken in the zip lock bag and shook it up untill both sides is covered well. finally I turned the deep fryer on 350 degrees made sure the oil was hot and dropped it in there for 15 minutes until it was cooked all the way through It was the first thing gone!

text:
Amazing!  We made it with a honey mustard sauce from this site. I cut up the thighs and made chicken fingers.  Update - This is the new recipe my husband says NOT to lose. I use 4 chicken breasts cut up which fills a chicken fryer sized pan 2x. I add 1 tsp salt, pepper, and garlic powder to the flour.  I forgot the potato flakes last time and it was still good.  I use 2 eggs and add hot sauce until they turn orange ( ala a paula deen recipe ) and I did just one shake of red pepper flakes.  This does not make it spicy, it just gives it some flavor.  My breasts are always frozen and cut and cooked when they are partially frozen, they are always really juicy.

I just made tried this recipe for my dinner tonight.  It was a definite hit, they totally loved it.  Added a few little extras for my own taste, but would highly recommend it to anyone.  A little more pepper and paprika and some Mrs. Dash - garlic and herb.  I did 6 minutes on the first side, then flipped and did another 6 on the second side...flipped and did each side again, for a total of 12 minutes on each side.  I made sure my oil was hot enough before putting them in.  It browned perfectly, nice crunch - fabulous flavor.  Will definitely make this again, that is for sure!  Even made some for leftovers as per other reviews...  Thanks so much!

text:
This is how my family has always made skinless boneless poultry!  I couldn't get enough as a kid-it's GREAT chilled.  Now that i'm older I use a ton of spices, including garlic and paprika, in the breading mix.  I suggest using 1, or even 2, of your favorite crackers for the crumbs and add an equal amount of potato flakes.  Also- if you're not a fan of pounding, it's easier to just butterfly the pieces.

Tried this recipe for supper this evening, and loved it!!  I used the chicken to make chicken burgers with mayonnaise and lettuce.  They tasted almost as good as KFC!!  I didn't have any potatoe flakes, but I did have potatoe flour (similar to corn starch)and I used this in place of the flour and omitted the potatoe flakes. This is a great recipe for when you feel like having something "comforting" with lots of fat and calories.  A great weekend meal!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is great! I read the reviews first and of course tweaked it a little. I used one whole package of saltine crackers, some salt, some pepper, some cayenne, some garlic salt (I don't measure). Instead of potato flakes (unavailable) I used maybe about a cup to a cup and a half of Frosted Flakes, and crushed-pulsed everything in a food processor then put it in a gallon ziplock. I also pounded out the chicken in a gallon zip lock and used two eggs instead of one. Good luck and enjoy!

text:
We now make this once a week.  Everyone loves it.  If I buy the thick breasts, I split them down the middle (butterfly like) I flour first (which I season, use your imagination) then dip in egg (I need 2 eggs) I used crushed club crackers the first 3 times I made this (which was soooo good!) but this last time I used chicken in a biscuit crackers and this put it over the top!  I used a med hi heat and just cooked until they were golden brown, they were perfect (let sit for a few min on paper towels before eating)

text:
I wish I could give this 10 stars !!!!!  This coating is out of this world good !!!!!!  I used unsalted topped saltines (we are salt sensative) put the entire sleeve of crackers in my mini food processor and crushed then I addd the rest of the ingrediants in the large ziplock bag exactly as written.  I had bought boneless skinless chicken cutlets because they were on sale and I am glad I used the thinner pieces of chicken.   I decided to dredge the chicken in flour, then in the egg and then in the cracker crust.  Heated up the oil in my deep fryer to 375 and fried for about 8 minutes until golden brown.  This fried chicken was wonderful !!!!!!  Thank You for sharing.

text:
So, this was my first time frying chicken, and I'll admit that I was not prepared for it. This is a very harrowing thing to do for the first time (and without tongs, no less)! I managed not to set the kitchen on fire, and produced some very tasty-looking fried chicken at the end.

However, the reason I am giving it two stars is because, made exactly the way the recipe is written, this tastes exactly like crackers on top of chicken. It needs a lot more flavor and seasoning, as several other reviewers stated, and I was disappointed in the outcome. I will have to play around with this more after I get up the nerve again, but the take-home lesson here is to come armed with additional ingredients, because these alone will not do it.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews I improvised by using panko bread crumbs, parsley, salt, pepper and Cajun spices.  Used only one egg for dipping the chicken pieces (took the skin off some but not all just for comparison).  I dipped the chicken pieces in egg and the seasoned bread crumbs, letting them air dry 1/2 hr.  Then sprayed a shallow pan w/ Pam and baked @ 350 as directed.  The chicken was crispy and plenty moist.with more than enough grease considering the small amount of oil used..My family loved it!!! Next time I will bake in the Foreman grill.

text:
Great recipe!! I have never been successful with fried chicken, but this came out perfect! The chicken was so juicy & the outside was mice & crunchy. I did add about a tsp each of paprika & garlic powder, and a little more potato flakes to the bag. I pounded out the chicken breast so they'd be even thickness, then cut into chunks. I then coated with flour first as another reviewer suggested, then dredged in the egg, then tossed in the zip lock baggie. Make sure your oil is very hot before putting the chicken in. Awesome recipe!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good! Ok, I was inspired by this recipe and here's mine:
- some garlic pita chips
- some regular pita chips
- some cornflakes
- flour and potato flakes as called for here
- seasoning is paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, very fresh ground black pepper, salt

1. Slice chicken thin
2. Beat your meat
3. Season meat (left over seasoning goes into greasing)
4. Cornstarch meat
5. Egg meat
6. Bread meat
7. Fry meat
8. Eat meat

text:
What a great coating for fried chicken! I'll be using this again. I didn't make it exactly as written but close enough. I did follow the one review about dredging in flour, then in the egg, and then into the crackers. Did the frying in an electric skillet at 350* and cooked until the internal temperature got to 180*. The chicken was very moist but not one bit rare. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I would rate this a 5, but changed it.  Sure it is wonderful as written, but added extra ingredients.  This is what I did - as other suggested I used an egg, but also added two tablespoons of Ranch dressing.  I also added two finely chopped jalapenos.  Instead of the saltines I used Keebler Buttery Garlic crackers.  It was very moist and we loved it.  I am thinking about adding chopped pecans to it the next time without the jalapenos.  Just all kind of things you can do with this wonderful recipe. Thanks CASSJW for a fantastic recipe.

Tried this tonight & the whole family loved it!  Only thing I did different was flour, egg(I used 2), then cracker mixture.  Added extra black pepper & garlic powder to the cracker mix.  I fried the chicken using 1/2 c. oil in a cast iron skillet.  The chicken was crispy on the outside and tender & juicy inside.   Even with using boneless, skinless chicken, the coating held onto the chicken beautifully.  I'll definitely make this again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe!  The flavor is great, and the crust is never soggy.  I also pound my chicken to "even" out the thickness, and as another reviewer suggested, I also coat with flour before dipping in egg and then crumbs.  After dredging, I let the chicken sit in the fridge for about 20-30 minutes to "set" the coating.  I think this makes a big difference.  I usually add a few drops of Louisiana Hot Sauce to the egg mixture just to give the flavor a little boost.  But, it is wonderful just the way the recipe stated also.  Try this for your Chicken Fried Steak and Chicken Fingers as well.  Very good!!

text:
Fabulous.  I have to confess that I have never fried chicken before, but the reviews were so good that I gave it a shot.  Turned out perfectly.  We had recently been to a pricey restaurant known for it's fried chicken.  THIS was better -- way better.  I turned up the seasonings a little for personal taste.  The crackers don't add as much salt to the recipe as you might think, so maybe add a bit of salt.  I soaked my chicken breasts in salt water for an hour or two before frying.  An instant family favorite.

text:
By far, this was the best chicken fried chicken recipe to make with boneless, skinless chicken breasts!  I didn't have the potato flakes, but the recipe turned out great anyway.  I did add some garlic powder and some parsley flakes (for color).  When the chicken looked done, I finished it in a 350 degree oven, just to make sure that it was completely cooked through.  I would NOT use thick chicken breasts...pound them out if you have fresh, thick ones.  My kids liked this, especially when dipped in gravy.
A big thumbs up from this (usually NON) chicken lover!

text:
This recipe was very tasty even with some modifications.  I did not have any potato flakes on hand, so I omitted them.  After coating the chicken with the egg and cracker mixture, I placed the pieces in a baking dish.  I then cut up a stick of unsalted butter into small pats and added them to the tops of the chicken.  I baked the dish for 45 minutes and presto, we had a delicious meal!  This recipe was a hit with my husband and little boys, all of whom are very picky.  I am looking forward to trying this recipe with the potato flakes as well.

text:
Wonderful!  We had this for dinner tonight and my husband said that I should open a restaurant! So easy!  I added Spike All Natural seasoning instead of seasoning salt (I ran out!) and marinated the chicken in a vidalia onion salad dressing for a little while before frying. I cut up the chicken into strips/chunks, skipped dipping them in the egg since they were already goopy from the salad dressing and fried them in the deep fryer for about 4-5 minutes at 360 degrees. WOW!  It was so easy and I didn't want to mess with the pan frying. Thanks for a great recipe!!

userID:
2405575
Display Name:
miss busy body
isPro:

followersCount:

13
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off this is an excellent base recipe that does need a bit of spices!  It was so great that I burned one and it still tasted great :) What I did was added 35 or so Honey Ritz Crackers, then added 1/2 a teaspoon of salt, 1 tblspoon pepper, 1 tblspoon garlic, 1 tblspoon basil, 2 tblspoons parmesan, a handful of total corn flakes, 2 tblspoons of flour and blended it in a high power mixer. The result smelled great and after using 2 egg yolks and thinly cut chicken I cooked them on low fire for 5 minutes on each side using the suggestion of switching to high immediately between placing new strips of chicken. The crust is crunchy and delicious and the inside is oh so yummy. The only downside is that I had to use a lot of oil, but still the result is heavenly.

Pretty darned good like that and more like my Dad's favorite version of chicken fried steak.

text:
I loved this recipe. It was my first time making chicken fried chicken and it was pretty easy. I would have given it a five with my minor changes. After reading other reviews, I added much more spices/flavor to the crumb/batter. I added cayene pepper, paprika, lemon pepper, lots of ground black pepper, garlic salt, and oregano. We love lots of flavor and hubby said it could have used even more spice/flavor to it.
I also used more oil than listed...just enough to really cover the bottom of my large pan.

YUMMY! This is one of my first times trying to fry anything, and I couldn't be more pleased with the outcome! I did, however, change a few things. As some of the other members suggested, I pounded the chicken before cooking it, and tinkered with the combination of seasonings. All in all, this is a great recipe and I will definately add this to my list of dinner ideas! Thanks!

all the positives I read in others reviews are all true - 
they were just like chicken fingers - breading didnt fall off the chicken as it usually does with fried chicken - 
DEF need garlic powder/poultry seasoning on the chicken before breading it, 
dont continously flip the chicken while frying it, i flipped each piece only once, the breading stayed on better this way

GREAT recipe, tasted just like that greasy disgustlying DELICIOUS chicken you get at a diner.  the boys loved it. thanks :)

text:
This is a terrific recipe! I was surprised at how good this turned out. I have been looking for a good recipe to use for chicken and have finally found it! Thanks! This will definately be added to our rotation. One note to others trying it. It's better if your crackers are not crushed too finely. I know the recipe basically says the same but I crushed mine because I was worried how the texture and taste would come out. It's better to leave the crackers in very small chunks because they will give the chicken a crunch even after frying. Very good!

text:
For my first time frying chicken, this was pretty good.  I added extra cajun seasoning, extra black pepper, and garlic powder, and everyone said they liked it, but the hubby said it needed some more seasoning.  Oh, I ran out of the cracker mixture before I ran out of meat because I'd chopped up the six breasts to chicken tender size, so if you're going to do that as well I'd recommend upping it by half (i.e. 45 crackers, 3 tbsp flour, etc.).  The hubby also said it would be interesting to try Ritz crackers next time, so we'll probably do that.

Deeeeeeeeelicious!  Followed the recipe exactly except I cut the ingredients by half and I used a deep fryer.  Because the deep fryer cooks so quickly, I had to hammer down the breast down to about 1.25 inches thick to make sure the inside gets cooked without the batter burning.  Now that I know how to make this at home, I don't need to go out to my favorite bar & grill place for country fried chicken anymore!

text:
My family (husband and two boys) *loved* this dish.  My 7-year old loved the breading, and my husband said the breading reminded him of breading on chicken fried steak.  I thought it was a tad bit bland, but I will try adding more seasoned salt next time -- and there will be a next time.  This one is a keeper.
The only thing I did different from the recipe, was that I "fried" the chicken in the oil, until browned on each side, but then I moved to the oven and baked for 20 minutes or so at 350 degrees.  Yummy!  thanks for sharing!

pretty easy process for fried chicken. i dumped all the flour mixture ingredients into a ziploc bag, just so a i didn't have another dish to wash. i used chicken breast tenders, cooked for the same amount of time, and they still were pretty juicy and tender. i added in garlic powder and "tabasco" seasoning salt to spice it up. very crunchy crust. tastes just like fried chicken with crunchy skin but not as greasy (and without the skin, less calories)!! quick and simple recipe.

text:
This is an amazing recipe! I have been looking for a chicken fried chicken recipe that gives a thick, crunchy coating and this recipe more than provides. I did stray from the recipe out of necessity, since I did not have potato flakes. Instead I added the equivalent in flour. I also added garlic powder to the recipe as well as the suggested season salt and the flavor turned out perfect.  This will now be my go-to recipe. Loved it.
I also made gravy using a couple tablespoons on the grease used to fry the chicken and some of the crunchy tid-bits that were left in the skillet after frying. It gave the gravy a really nice flavor and complimented the chicken really well.

I made this last night and everybody loved it. I have a very picky 7 year old (and an almost as picky boyfriend) so finding recipes they like tends to be pretty hard. I added both the 1 t. garlic powder and 1 t. paprika from the other reviews and changed the half t. pepper to a full teaspoon and about 20 crackers instead of the 30. I used the tenders instead of breasts and did the flour, egg, and then the cracker mix. They both liked it so much they made me promise to make it again later this week. This one is definitely going in the recipe book.

text:
Good flavor base in the coating, and I like the idea of using crushed crackers.  But for some reason, even though I heated the oil to 350 degrees as the recipe said, my coating burned before my chicken was done.  I tried it both on chicken breasts and on bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs, with the same result.  The breasts ended up dry and burnt inside and out.  The thighs took longer to cook, which meant more burning.  Not a recipe for a beginner at frying, like me.

country:
None
text:
I used this recipe for the first time I ever made fried chicken, and it was pretty good. I mean, the chicken certainly looked and tasted like fried chicken. However, in my opinion, the flavor was lacking a little. It was semi-bland and needed more salt (surprisingly). Next time I make this, I think I'll add 1/2 tsp garlic salt, and that should address both problems. Also, I fried mine in a skillet with canola oil and maybe that was why, but it took MUCH longer than 15-20 minutes to fry 6 pieces of chicken. I had 4 legs and 2 breasts. I did the legs two at a time, then the breasts one at a time and the total frying time was about an hour and 15 minutes.

Really good and easy! I pounded out 4 chicken breasts into cutlets, and this was the perfect amount of breading.  No seasoned salt, so just added salt and pepper to the flour mix.  Had no veg. oil, so I cooked it in bacon grease - just a couple of tbsp. in a nonstick electric skillet. Chicken was really juicy! Thanks for the recipe, I'll be making this again!

country:
None
text:
Using the other reviews as a guide I changed this up a bit.  I used about 30 saltines, a huge handful of goldfish crackers, and some spices for the coating.  I didn't have an egg so I mixed about a cup of milk and 1-2 tablespoons of mayo as the egg dip.  I started the chicken by pounding it flatter, coated it in dry flour, then the mayo mixture and finally into the cracker/spice mixture.  
The chicken was moist and tender and the coating was delicious!  Next, I will try this modified recipe with steak.  Yum!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-09-24T18:19:27.807
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
7124019
Display Name:
TulsaCook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
117
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was awesome! I made just a few changes. First, I used 1 lb chicken tenders instead of breasts and I omitted the potato flakes as I didn't have any. I also used 2 eggs, and I reduced the amount of pepper to 1/4 t because I didn't want my kids to tell me this was "too spicy". Then I dipped the chicken in egg, dredged in flour, dipped in buttermilk, then coated in the cracker mixture. This was just barely enough cracker crumbs to coat all of the chicken pieces, so I will adjust accordingly next time. Cooked in about 1/2 cup of canola oil (because my skillet was really big and deep) for about 3-4 minutes on each side, about 5 tenders at a time. It turned out so light and crispy and was cooked just perfectly on the inside. Fabulous, and my kids LOVED these and even asked for seconds, which is practically unheard of at my house. My daughter even asked me if I would make this more often, so this recipe is definitely a keeper!! Served it with country gravy, mashed potatoes and green beans...great comfort food! Husband and I decided I could have definitely used the full amount of pepper called for without the chicken being spicy, so I'll definitley do that next time to add just a bit more flavor. Thanks for sharing!!

text:
This was really good. I have never been a fan of cracker crumbs, usually opting for breadcrumbs or flouring instead, but I was really impressed! I kind of made it my own... had no flake potato so used 3 tbs of flour instead of 2, generous amounts of garlic powder and seasoning salt and I was out of eggs so I used Ranch dressing with a little milk. My kids loved it! After frying in vegetable oil, I saved about 1/4 cup of the drippings and made "milk" gravy in my skillet.

country:
None
text:
I Read all the reviews before trying this, and I did adjust the recipe for servings of 9.  Increased the seasoned salt 1 T and potato flakes 1T, added about 1T of garlic powder, and used seasoned flour instead of regular.  Also I floured the chicken before the egg dredging.  The only thing I wished I had done was cut the breasts either in kinda large strips or the breasts in half or thirds.  But when thinking of this method please remember the breasts I use are approx 1 to 1.25 pounds each.  In a 12" skillet I can only fit 1 breast at a time.  I did flatten them a little just so they would cook through easier.  If you can find a good old fashioned meat market with fresh boneless breasts, they are much better than anything you can get.  I will definitely do this recipe again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good starting point for pan-frying chicken.  I had never tried it before, mostly out of fear.  I followed the advice of almost everyone... First I marinated boneless skinless chicken brest for an hour in EVOO, salt, pepper, adobo, and minced garlic.  I made a breading of crushed club crackers, instant potato flakes, salt, pepper, papricka, onion powder, and garlic powder.  As someone suggested, after I pounded out the chicken, I dredged it in flour, then egg wash, and then my breading mixture.  I pan fried in veggie oil (it can withstand high temps. more so than OO.) to a light brown.  I served it with green bean casserole and a gravy I threw together by making a roux and adding chicken stock (I always keep on hand). Long story short, DEL-ISH!!!!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
So good! However, most of the credit isn't towards the recipe, though I did incorporate everything it called for. I added a LOT too it though because the breading was too bland, which is what made it so good. This simple recipe leaves a lot open to the chef so you can add anything you want. I added a lot of garlic, paprika, and a bit of chili powder. Wonderful. I fried a bunch of wings, tips discarded, and they were fantastic. As others have mentioned, flour the chicken before dipping in the egg mixture. Also, I ran out of egg and didn't want to crack another one for the last couple of wings, so I dredged them in honey mustard and it was AWESOME!

text:
This was so easy and tasted AMAZING.  I have never made fried chicken before so I was nervous, but it came out GREAT.  It took me a really long time to crush up the crackers, but other than that I had no problems.  I also took the advice of other reviewers and added a LOT more seasoned salt and some garlic powder, tasting as I went.  I also pounded the chicken with a little water first, then coated it in flour, then egg, then the cracker mixture. This is definitely going to become a regular meal at my house.
