text:
I received this recipe from my best friend and my family just loves it!! She suggested adding 1/2 a packet of dry ranch dressing to the cracker mixture instead of flour.  I also coated the pieces in flour first (or fry mix) before dipping in egg.  The chicken turned out perfect.  We loved the recipe so much that I used it for chicken fried steak, which is now a family favorite.  Tip:  Be careful to monitor the heat of the oil because the coating can burn easily if you are not careful. Thanks to CASSJW and my best friend for sharing this recipe!

I had some buttermilk to use up, so I soaked chicken tenders in the buttermilk first, for about 20 minutes, then dipped them in the coating when ready to cook. text:
This recipe is absolutely delicious! My family couldn't get enough of it. I did make a few small adjustments. I followed a few other reviewers suggestions about dipping the chicken in flour, egg, then in the cracker mixture. I used more crackers and added a little more of the spices than suggested. I also included a little garlic powder to taste. This was not the least bit bland. I was amazed at how well the cracker mixture adhered to the chicken and stayed there even through frying.I have used other recipes that the cracker mixture fell off before it hit the pan or it didn't even stick at all. Not this one. This was perfect!

userID:
1959019
Display Name:
lisap
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
44
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good...however, I did make a few changes/additions.  Per another reviewer's suggestion, I was able to find "Cracker Mix", which is essentially crackers that have already been finely ground.  I used 1 cup of this, increased potato flakes to 3 TBS, and added a few dashes of onion and garlic powder.  I used thin sliced boneless chicken breasts, sprinkled them with Weber Kick'n Chicken seasoning (don't put to much--it is spicy!), salt and pepper, then dredged in egg and shook in bag of dry mixture until coated.  I increased oil to 1/3 cup and cooked covered for approx. 20 minutes, turning only once as suggested by another reviewer.  Very good, but I'm not sure how good it would have been without the addition of the Kick'n Chicken!

My boyfriend & I made this the other night, and it was SO good, and very filling. We made it with mashed potatoes from scratch and gravy. We didn't go -exactly- by the recipe, for the seasoned salt we used season all, not sure if that would be considered the same thing as the salt, and we used seasoned pepper instead of regular black pepper. It came out just as good, if not better than something from Dennys or Marie Callendars Chicken fried Chicken :) Thanks, we will be making this again.

text:
Wow! Just the recipe I have been looking for! I made the crumbs fine instead of course and made a white sauce chicken gravy. Can't wait to make it again - Comes out perfect every time. I add sweet paprika, pepper and a dash of all purpose seasoning and a dash of seasoning salt. I leave out the flour from the crumb mixture, as suggested before, I dip the chicken in the flour first, then the egg (I mix a little buttermilk in with the egg) and then in the crumb mixture. My entire family LOVES THIS CHICKEN! Definitely a keeper! Thank you so much for sharing!! :0)

userID:
1501679
Display Name:
Princess Petunia
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/22737.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time I’ve ever made fried anything, and the crust stayed on. Cassie Wicks, God bless you :oD 

I pounded the chicken breasts until they were pretty thin, & well, mangled.  The first one, I used the - I’m sorry, I don’t know the technical term for it - the bumpy side of the food hammer thing, and it looked odd, like it had been gnawed by a wild animal, so the next one I just used the flat side.  I then sprinkled them with salt, pepper, garlic & onion powder, & set them in the fridge for an hour. 

Now, I had a problem with the amounts of things.  I always have a problem with this type of thing, so it may very well be just my own ignorance. Nevertheless, I used 2 eggs instead of one because the chicken was huge after it had been pounded. And I used an entire sleeve of saltines, again because of the size of the chicken, and Parmesan cheese - about half a cup - instead of potato flakes, about half a cup of flour, & a LOT more oil than was called for.  And this was for only two breasts. ( ! )

Anyway, the end result was really very pretty, and tasty.  NONE of the crust fell off while it was cooking, which has never EVER happened for me before, so I am so super tickled about that.  The crust is a bit bland on its own, but if you season your chicken, it is a delightful crust, & compliments the meat very nicely, in my opinion.  And my very particular husband liked it, so that settles it for me.  This is most assuredly something I will be using again.

text:
Yum!  I added extra seasoning, at other's recommendation, good thing, I still could've added more!  The crust is wonderful and the chicken was juicey.  I did flour the chicken before the egg wash, seemed to help the coating stick.  I pan fried these in my iron skillet and, since my chicken breasts were so big and thick, I put them in the oven at 300F to finish cooking (if it needed it), plus I needed to cook the rest of the chicken.  I finished the meal and cleaned up the kitchen while these were in the oven (15 min. at most).  Mashed potatoes and sweet peas were my side items.  My dh piled his plate up and ate it all, said it hit the spot and rubbed it out!  I like that!

text:
i dredge the chicken pieces in flour first, so the egg wash has something to stick to, then omit the flour from the breading mixture.  you can leave out the cracker crumbs and just use potato flakes if you're in a hurry.  this is a light and tasty breading and my whole family loves chicken done this way - we've always called it "fish fried chicken" or "chicken fish"

text:
This was so delicious and it is even more yummy the next day when it is cold.  This has now become my fried chicken recipe.  My daugher will even eats this like it is candy.  She usually never eats much fried chicken.  She is only 3 and all day long she will go in at the fridge and get some. I cut a big piece up for her in there.  My son who is 10 ate 4 pieces for dinner.  Haven't seen him eat that much in a long time.  So, this is definately a keeper at our house and I look forward to sharing the recipe with friends.  I think I will have a family get together and make this chicken.  I followed the recipe exact except I used more egg to dip the chicken in.  I think I used like 4 eggs.  I had some huge chicken breasts and was able to cut some into two-three pieces.  So, don't know since I had like 20 pieces of chicken if that is why I needed more egg.  The breaded ingredients were just enough for all the chicken I had.  Thanks for sharing this recipe.  :o)

text:
I have used a similar recipe for years, the potato flakes are totally optional. I use flour, then egg wash, then crushed saltines. I let them sit in the fridge for about 30 mins so the breading locks in good and then I fry them. So good with a little Italian dressing drizzled on them ! This recipe is also great for mild tasting fish, such as Pacific Whiting, Swai, Cod, Pollack..

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fiancé is on a low fod  map diet so I used gluten-free flour blend and rice crispies ground up about 1 1/2 cups each,  Salt, pepper, Cayenne pepper, and a dash of thyme.  I used chicken tenderloin strips and dipped them in an egg wash of one egg and almond milk then tossed them in the coating.  I fried them in sunflower olive oil combination with just a little bit of bacon fat. THEY WERE GREAT.  The potato flakes I think made them wonderful! He is a picky eater and he loves them. THEY were VERY moist.  I served with salad and jasmine rice with butter. Thanks for this recipe, chef!! The oil is conquistador brand  olive oil combination, it’s a terrific oil and I bought it at a Mexican shopping center!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4706759.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WE ALL LOVED THIS!  Okay, so very few changes per our taste and cooking style and it was fantastic. 
Using cut-up boneless breast, wash then pat dry.
Next: We added salt & pepper to the flour, then drench chicken pieces in that first.
THEN dip in egg - flour first, then egg.
Next, you go to the cracker mix after the egg.  We also added salt, pepper, marjoram, and dill seasonings to the cracker mix and I think that helped because it was a hit.  Very flavorful and I was asked the same week to make it again.
Thank you, CASSJW, this is a keeper!
Update - made it again for some guests and everyone loved it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made as is, except I ended up making more of the cracker mixture part-way thru, and using two more eggs. I was running out, mainly because I used boneless skinless breasts, and cut them into chicken strips, so I had a lot more surface area to cover. This is a new favorite. I would double the cracker recipe and use three or four eggs when doing strips, and adding more salt or flavor to the mixture.  Note to self: oven setting between 4-5 to keep oil the correct temperature.  Cook the strips about 4-5 minutes per side, and they'll turn out mid- to dark brown and crispy. Thanks for sharing!!

text:
I made this recipe with chicken tenderloins and nuggets cut from tenderloins. In addition to the recipe ingredients, I added 1 tsp each of garlic powder and parsley and 1/2 tsp of paprika. The coating was tasty and crispy, but there are no wild flavors here; if I didn't have to feed kids, I might prefer more spice. This was super easy to make using a food processor - the 12 year old felt pretty accomplished. The kids insisted that this recipe tastes like a Chik-Fil-A copycat; I wouldn't go that far. The kids loved it, but to be fair, they've never met a chicken nugget they didn't like. I will almost certainly make this again.

text:
I made this on a whim, I had chicken breasts out and was at a loss what to do.  I followed this as close as my pantry allowed me to and it was fantastic!  I would have never thought about using fake potatoes in breading but I feel like it really thickened it up.  I did dredge in flour first, then egg, then the breading.  I browned them in my cast iron skillet, then finished in the oven.  325 for about 15 minutes... the flavor was awesome and the chicken was still moist.  Thank you!  This is a keeper and will be going in my recipe book!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I made some changes: 
1. Always brine chicken beforehand at least 30 min.
2. Added buttermilk (I made my own with apple cider vinegar and milk) and hot sauce to egg  for better coating and flavor.
3. Hand coated the breading instead of shaking it. Much better coating though messier!
4. Added adobo seasoning and garlic powder to coating mix.
5. Baked chicken once heated to 160 degrees in oven for 5 minutes at 350 degrees to ensure doneness.
6. Used legs and thighs with bone and skin.

My family loved this chicken! My husband ate four pieces and it was juicy thanks to the brine!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base for fried chicken!  I used another reviewers suggestion and dredged in flour first then egg and then cracker coating. I did add some seasonings to the crackers...seasoned salt, garlic powder, a pinch of cayenne.  Tried to keep oil at 350, which seems to be the perfect temp for getting a good crunch without burning the coating. Used meat thermometer to watch my tenderized breast tenders so they didn't over cook. Definitely not a "hands off" dish, you have to stay with it the whole time, but worth it!
Review:

Display Name:

text:
I followed the recipe and directions exactly as described with 1 exception - I had to substitute the Saltines with Club crackers (no Saltines on hand). I don't normally fry food, but I was desperate for a quick and easy meal that used chicken breasts. I was so glad I gave this a try! It was very good- tender, crispy, flavorful.  I used a meat thermometer in the oil to make sure it stayed at the right temp and then stabbed it into the breasts at the end of cook time to make sure they were completely cooked. Whole family loved them! I will definitely be fitting this into our dinner rotation. Thanks!

text:
We didn't have saltines, so I used Ritz. It turned out so good I mixed up a little more and used it for fried okra. It was salty, I'm guessing because of the RItz, but that's the way my husband likes it, so I wouldn't change a thing. As far as cook time, it was on the table at an edible temp (slightly cooled) by the 20 minute of cook time mark, so it cooked faster than expected, probably in 15 minutes (I did quarter my breasts). I cooked on just over medium heat with a good sizzle the entire time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As is with any recipe, technic is important.  Personal taste is also key.  Like other comments, I added paprika but took out some of the salt. I didn't have all the saltines so I added Ritz. This give a depth of buttery richness we like but can add salty which we don't. So that's why I used less salt.  I used boneless breasts!!!! But I don't flattened them, I cut them in chunks.   I cooked them about 6 minutes per side and depending on how thick they are, that should be good.  They were so moist and juicy.  My whole picky family loved these so I will be making this recipe from now on. ps I completely agree that the coating must be quite dark not golden brown to get the full flavor and keep in the moistness

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  I love this recipes!  I made my chicken with skinless legs and thighs since my husband would rather eat dark meat. I'm all about flavor so after looking at some of the suggestions for spices, I added 1 tsp each of garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, parsley flakes, seasoning salt and Cavender's Greek Seasoning.  I added about 1/2 tsp fresh ground black pepper. I use a tube of saltines and crush them coarsely with a rolling pin. I fry in a iron skillet at a medium heat for about 25 minutes.  My family loves it!

In a very budget-minded week I planned to make this dish, but found that I didn't have all the ingredients.  Instead of crackers, I crumbed a half-bag of pretzels, added 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 tsp of salt, 1 tsp of pepper, 2 tbsp. flour, dipped in 2 eggs then the mix.  Then baked at 425 degrees until chicken was done.  Turned out delicious and with everything we already had in the kitchen!

text:
I started this recipe before I checked for saltines. I should have known better in a house full of teenage boys, there's never what you need when you need it!
I scrambled through the kitchen and decided to use the crumbs in the bottom of a couple of Doritos bags.
I tripled the recipe (loosely) and used approximately equal parts of potato flakes, flour & Doritos crumbs. 
I used the seasoned salt and black pepper and added some garlic powder (about equal to the seasoning salt)- because everything is better with garlic.
I also used cubed chicken breasts- not bone-in chicken.
And I did flour the chicken before the egg dip- I always have, and it always seems crispier that way.
 I assume they were great, because as the batches came out of the fryer, they were devoured. I never got to actually try them, but 4 out of 5 boys have asked when I'm making them again!
I look forward to the next batch!

text:
I changed the amount of seasoned salt to 1 TABLEspoon and added a tablespoon of granulated garlic.  I also took a reviewer's suggestion to dip the chicken first in flour, then in egg and then in the breading.  It turned out delicious!  We will definitely be making it again.  I cut my breasts and thighs into thirds to make more manageable portion sizes.  We had a lot leftover so I reheated it the next day by bringing the pieces to room temperature and then baking at 357° Farenheit for 20 minutes, and it was every bit as good as the first time around.  Next time I will try freezing leftovers and reheating in the oven.  I think it could make for a great freezer meal!

userID:
9108286
Display Name:
Cindy Burr
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
421
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several reviews before trying it, we made sure to use lots of extra flavorings.  First, we bought potato flakes that had garlic seasoning already mixed in.  I added the flakes to the flour and put that into one bowl.  I put the finely crushed crackers, 1 T seasoned salt, 1 t. black pepper, 1 t. garlic powder, 1/2 t. paprika and 1/2 t. poultry seasoning all together into another bowl.  The 3rd bowl had the blended egg.  I dredged the chicken in the flour/flake mix, then the egg, then the cracker and topped with another coating of the flour/flake mix.  Also, my mom always left her chicken sit for about 10 minutes after coating it so that it would "adhere" a little better to the chicken.  Also, make sure your chicken isn't too crowded in the skillet, it needs room so you can flip it without removing the coating.  The pieces really shouldn't touch while they are frying.  My husband and I made this for his mom and dad and we all enjoyed the flavor and the crispiness.  We would make it again.  I hate altering a recipe so much as far as the spices but I can see where it might be rather bland without it.

Great recipe. My hard to please kids thought it was the best chicken we ever had. I substituted Panko for the potato flakes and I followed some of the other reviewers ideas; cutting the pieces into tenders, using flour before the egg dash and i added garlic powder. Next time I will fool around with adding more spices. I used corn oil at a medium/low setting and put in six peices at a time turning every two minutes until they were dark brown. The crust is excellant and the chicken was tender, hot, and juicy. Winner!

Amazing recipe. My family was raving for hours!!! soooooo easy and the flavor/ crispiness is perfect. My chicken breast were huge so I sliced them in 1/2 lenghtwise and it cut down on the cooking time.  All the ingredients married very well together.  This recipe is mow a staple in my home.

None
text:
Thumbs up for this recipe!    It's incredibly easy, don't have to buy the generic brands, use ingredients that was sitting in your pantry for many years (e.g. crackers), and it actually looks like fried chicken. If I may say so, it's even better than restaurants'.  It also gets more kudos with how easy it is to customize in the seasoning department.  If you want it salty but with a garlic taste, add more garlic to the flour-bread mixture.  If you don't, then take away.    It's very easy and, with just one trial, made it my ultimate default for fried chicken.  Thank you for this amazing recipe!

text:
I intended on following this recipe to a T, but as I was about to cook, my computer was too slow in getting the recipe up, but I remembered the basics, so I put it together anyway. I just put flour in a bowl, without measuring, I added crushed taco shells, because I didn't have saltines, and I added some seasoned salt, pepper, garlic powder, and basil,(I didn't measure any of these, just seasoned to taste). After frying in the oil until browned, I baked in the oven for a while longer to ensure the drumsticks were cooked through. This was a very good recipe, and the family really seemed to like it.

text:
I decided to cook for my boyfriend for the first time ever (he's more of the chef) and went with this recipe. I went with someone's suggestion in adding the hot sauce, red pepper flakes, and more salt seasoning and it turned out fantastic! The first three I fried I dipped only once and it came out good, but the second time around I dipped the chicken twice (egg, mix, egg, mix) and the chicken turned out even better! My boyfriend gave it two thumbs up and said it had to be the best chicken he had in long time! This recipe is worth holding on to!

..This is an updated review since I have used this recipe numerous times since my first review. This remains to be hands down a favorite in our kitchen. The secret, in my opinion, is pounding the chicken! I let my oil get to 350 degrees before frying. I only fry 2 chicken breasts at a time and cook for 5 minutes on each side. This method hasn't failed me and has worked well for me. I hope this helps :)

text:
I made these last night for dinner and they were a huge hit!  I didn't have saltines so I just used buttered round crackers I had on hand.  I also cut the recipe in half to serve just two people and it was enough food, but there were no leftovers using the thinly sliced chicken breasts.  Next time I'll make extra because they'd make great leftovers for lunch.  I bought a box of potato flakes, used the called for amount for the recipe and used the rest of the opened package to make a side of mashed potatoes and also heated up some canned corn for a side.  It was a delicious, balanced meal!

text:
This recipe was simply amazing.  I like flavourful food and so I seasoned the chicken with spices that I like for 7 hours in the fridge.  I added 3 tablespoons of potatoe flakes and one tablespoon of flour.  I wanted a slightly different flavour.  I try and shy away from fried food so I followed the recommendation that another review wrote and baked it at 400 degree in baking tray for one hour so that I would get a crispy coat and it was great.  We had 10 pieces of chicken and the four of us devoured it.  The kids kept wanting more.  Goodbye KFC!!

The chicken stayed very moist, but other than that, this recipe was pretty unremarkable.  It was okay--kind of bland (even with some extra seasonings thrown on).  To it's credit, the breading actually stuck to the chicken, although I coated the chicken in flour before the egg and also cooked the chicken on each side for 5 minutes at a time.  

Probably wouldn't make it again, but it's a good starting point to tweak from.

Very good. It is important to note I made the following changes though - I added garlic salt, onion powder, & fried chicken seasoning to cracker/flour mix. I mixed 1/c cup of milk w/ the egg mixture. I dipped the chicken in the milk egg mixture, then in the dry flour mixture, then in another bowl of just plain beaten eggs and then fried them. The chicken was moist and delicious. Definitely a winner in our household.

userID:
1404080
Display Name:
ANJOISM
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AHK. My family and I loved this!! We all agreed it was better then, say, KFC or any other chicken fast food restaurants. Of course, me being me, I HAD to make a few changes.

I replaced the potato flakes with grated parmesan cheese, added one more egg (I used four medium-sized chicken breasts), and used cajun seasoning and garlic powder. Also, I cut the breasts into smaller pieces, and thereafter pounded it with my meat mallet. A great stress reliever ^__^

I "deep-fried" it for approximately three to four minutes, two minutes per side, then proceeded to bake it in a 350 degrees F oven for another four or five odd minutes. Fifteen minutes is far too long. However, DO NOT REDUCE the heat to medium! Just stick with seven or eight.

All in all, I definitely recommend this.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-02-10T04:31:28.577
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1706494
Display Name:
